intro: Lepyrodia interrupta, commonly known as the interrupted lepidote, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in shrubland or grassland habitats. Its leaves are usually narrow and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in a compact head. Lepyrodia interrupta is relatively rare and is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and limited distribution.
